summary: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is a cancer of the white blood cells, specifically a type of chronic leukemia. It is characterized by the increased and unregulated growth of myeloid cells in the bone marrow and their accumulation in the blood. CML is a clonal bone marrow stem cell disorder associated with a characteristic chromosomal translocation called the Philadelphia chromosome, which creates the BCR-ABL fusion gene. This gene produces an abnormal protein that causes leukemia cells to grow out of control, crowding out healthy blood cells and leading to infection, anemia, and bleeding.
causes: Abnormal BCR-ABL protein (tyrosine kinase) leading to uncontrolled cell growth
symptoms: Pain or fullness below the ribs on the left side
diagnosis: Blood chemistry tests (e.g., Basic Metabolic Panel, Comprehensive Metabolic Panel, kidney function tests, liver function tests, electrolyte panel)
Genetic tests for gene and chromosome changes
Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) for BCR-ABL1
Imaging tests (e.g., MRI, CT, ultrasound) for cancer spread
treatments: High-dose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant
